Message.Title: Discuss the Cyprus Deal - I think it's a wise.
Message.Msg: I can see why this is sending a ripple to markets today and maybe this week. It's a little scary to believe in the possibility that bondholders, shareholders, and uninsured depositors be left with the capitalization bill should a bank go insolvent. However, these comments by Dijsselbloem defending this action make sense to me. Why should tax payers or governments be left with a bill to cover risks taken by those investing in the bank? Why not charge them? "If there is a risk in a bank, our first question should be 'Okay, what are you in the bank going to do about that? What can you do to recapitalise yourself?'. If the bank can't do it, then we'll talk to the shareholders and the bondholders, we'll ask them to contribute in recapitalising the bank, and if necessary the uninsured deposit holders," he said. “If I finance a bank and I know if the bank will get in trouble, I will be hit and I will lose money, I will put a price on that,” Mr Dijsselbloem said. “I think it is a sound economic principle. And having cheap money because the risk will be covered by the government, and I will always get my money back, is not leading to the right decisions in the financial sector.” I agree that this is a sound economic principle and will put healthy bank stock prices up in the near term. In the long term, it's good for banks and good for governments. Thoughts? Read more: http://www.businessinsider.com/dijsselbloem-cyprus-deal-is-a-template-2013-3#ixzz2OZfTAgzy

Topic.Title: Discuss the Cyprus Deal - I think it's a wise.

Message.Msg: Right as innocent as the shareholder may be in that situation, they should be the ones to pay before tax payers. Shareholders took the risk. The taxpayers didn't! Also, in your example, if the depositors didn't like the fees, they should have switched banks. No reason to make tax payers pay for every bad decision made by other people. If banks knew the tax payers wouldn't bail them out, they don't take the risks. Cyprus is like a small sacrificial lamb to send a message to the rest of the global banks. Keep it clean or go out of business.
